a1: A file hash is a unique fingerprint generated from the file contents using a cryptographic algorithm. Even a tiny change in the file produces a completely different hash.
q2: Which hash algorithm should I use?
a2: SHA-256 is the most commonly used for file verification. SHA-1 is older and less secure. SHA-384 and SHA-512 offer stronger security.
a3: No, all hash computation happens in your browser using the Web Crypto API. Your files never leave your device.
a4: MD5 is not supported by the Web Crypto API and is considered cryptographically broken. We use SHA family algorithms which are more secure.
